syringe bulb, ann fill the vial with 70% alcohol. Wash in 70% until the eggs
are white. It is advisable to avoia washing toe long in 70%, since the stain
is best when it does not penetrate the maoromeres. These latter should,
therefare, be left acid. Thus the eggs are removed from 70% immediately
after the last wash which removes no picric acid from them, hyerated in 50%, 35%
and washed thoroughly in 2-3 changes of water.
C. ?tgining: After washing with water, fill the vial with undiluted Mayer*s
haem-alum, and stain for 5-10 minutes. For the polar stages, 5~7 minutes is
usually sufficient. After staining, wash thoroughly in water, dehyurate, and
clear in xylol; Remove the xylol useu in clearing and replace it with a small
amount of thin damer.
D. Mounting: Cover glasses must be supported. For this purpose it has been cone
venient to use payer squares the size of 7/8" cover glasses. A hole is punched
in the center of eaeh square with a paper punch. In mounting, the squares are
eleareu in xylol, and fixed to the eenters of the sliues by adding three or four
drops of thin oemar before the evaporation of the xylol. When the paper mounts
have dried the eggs are removed frum the vials in which they have been stored by
the use of a pipette urawn out to a long taper and having a small diameter at its
tip. The eggs are allowed to settle toward the tip of the pipette, and one drop
uf the egg-demar suspension is placed in the eenter depression of each paper
mount. The damar is allowed to ary to the point of formation of a thin film in
oruer that the eggs may remain dispersed ann with the macromere quartette ao-
jaoent to the sliee when mounted. Apply thick namar to the e&ge of the pager
mount, immerse a #0 cover glass in xylol ann apply it to the sliue over the paper
mount .
A. The Veliwer Larva of Crep;aulg 
Stuey the tynioal H?ligg? larva of Qggnicata. Obtain material
by breaking the animal from the substrate tu whioh it is attached. You will find
the yellowish eggs (enclosed in transparent capsules) attached to the substrate or
in the shell of the mother. Tease the embryos out of the capsules., Gbtain swimming
larvae in different stages, particularly ole ones with the yolk resorbed. They
are transparent ann show the inner organs. Consult Gogklin (1897) figs. 80-82 and
the text hooks of gaswell volume 1 (1928) fig. 657  u p. 734, or Egg?ride
figs. 263 ff. on pages 301 ff. or Kar chelt volume 2 (l936) pp 88l~89l, Study
dorsal, ventral ann lateral views. Mouth and foot are an the ventral sine; the
anus is on the right sine.
